name: Talbutal
summary: Talbutal is a barbiturate previously used as a sedative-hypnotic for insomnia and as a pre-anesthetic, now rarely used due to safety concerns and availability of safer alternatives.
description: Talbutal is a short- to intermediate-acting barbiturate that was once prescribed for the short-term treatment of insomnia and for pre-anesthetic sedation. Like other barbiturates, it works by enhancing the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA at the GABA-A receptor, leading to CNS depression. Due to its high potential for dependence, overdose risk, and the development of tolerance, Talbutal use has largely been replaced by safer medications such as benzodiazepines and non-benzodiazepine hypnotics. It is classified as a Schedule III controlled substance in the U.S., though it is rarely prescribed today.

off_label_uses: Occasionally used for seizure control (historical use)

sections.text: Enhances the activity of the inhibitory neurotransmitter GABA at the GABA-A receptor complex, leading to increased chloride ion influx and neuronal hyperpolarization, resulting in sedation and hypnosis.

adult.oral: Typical adult dose for insomnia was 100 mg at bedtime; dosing individualized based on indication and patient tolerance.

sections.text: Onset of action within 30–60 minutes; duration of sedative effect approximately 4–8 hours.

other: High risk of dependence, tolerance, and withdrawal symptoms
Potential for fatal overdose, especially when combined with alcohol or other CNS depressants
Avoid in elderly due to increased sensitivity and fall risk

sections.pregnancy: Not recommended; potential teratogenicity and neonatal withdrawal risk
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; may cause sedation in infant
sections.geriatrics: Avoid use due to increased fall and confusion risk

sections.text: Gradually reduce dose over several days to weeks to prevent withdrawal symptoms.

items: Use has declined due to safety concerns and the availability of safer alternatives
Withdrawal can be severe and potentially life-threatening
Historically used in combination with other sedatives in multi-ingredient products
